posts.com:
If you are a /beg/inner or /int/ermediate in art, please use this thread to post pieces for critique or ask for advice.
Use this thread instead of making new threads or post in the drawthread with fundamental exercises.

RESIZE YOUR IMAGES TO ~1000 PIXELS wide using one of the following methods:
1. screenshot the image and post that instead
2. change camera capture settings to something smaller
3. send to computer and resize in MSPaint

READ THE STICKY:
Completed: https://docs.google.com/document/d/1uwaXKU7ev6Tw_or__o8ARpUb6r2rCZYJGqwSFV9AD98/edit
New collaborative sticky (anyone can edit): https://hackmd.io/UMnZVhNITW-T2wZpHw6d0Q
Old: http://www.squidoo.com/how-to-draw-learn

RECOMMENDED BOOKS FOR BEGINNERS:
Read the sticky

TRY TO BE ACTIVE AND GIVE PEOPLE SOME FEEDBACK.
When giving feedback, avoid vague "advice" - point what's wrong and try to give the anon you're quoting a clear direction to improve their art (study heads < watch THIS VIDEO about head structure, read THIS SECTION of THIS ARTIST'S BOOK, etc).
You, feedback seeking anon, should also try to be clear and concise when asking for critique/help. When posting your artwork, say what you want help with, and what's your goal with the study/artwork.

Previous Thread: >>6427352

>>6423332
Instead of taking a course, do the following every day for a week:

Write down a list of at least 5 things you like. Does not have to be only artists, can be media of any sort, or hell even odd shit like food if you want.

Make a venn diagram. Label it with one of the 5 subjects.
Write what you want to learn from the subject, artwise, in the middle
Write what you already can do as good or better than the subject in the left
Write what you don't like/care about the subject in the right.

Repeat for each of the daily 5.

---

It's an exercise for self-awareness and understanding your influences and where you want your directions to go. When you have done all these you can then use that knowledge to know what you wanna study from the different subjects. Character design is downstream from that stuff.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6418102
Push your contrasts. Physical media and monitors both have limited blacks and whites compared to real life. That's why you have sacrifice value range in either the shadows or the lit side to give a lifelike effect. Photographs don't do that by default to not lose information. There's too much contrast between small shapes while having a lack of proper light and dark seperation of major shapes.
If you adjust the contrast a bit on both and posterize you can notice these issues more easily.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Say OP how do you position everything so accurately? How to train that skill?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6426324
I use a couple methods. If I’m drawing sight-size, I will drag a line across from the other image to locate the top and bottom of the head and other major features. Then it’s in the right place horizontally and I only need to figure out vertical placement. I did that with the first drawing. But I also use angles. I angle my pencil/charcoal against the line of the side of the face, the side of the forehead, etc., and then move over to my paper and start drawing while it’s still at that angle. This helps locate things too, because, for example, the angle of the nose and the eyebrow should meet at the right place and then I can place the eye. That’s what I mainly did for the second drawing.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6366575
>spend more than 10 minutes
All my drawing attempts are agonzingly slow as I spend ages deliberating every single line. I can't imagine getting something done in only ten minutes.
>pick an easier subject
I genuinely don't understand what supposedly makes a subject easier or harder to draw. Everything past basic geometric shapes/forms seems impossibly difficult. I've seen people claim that rocks and trees are easy, which seems crazy to me given that they have such incredibly complex shapes and textures.
>copy literal lines and squares that you drew
I can copy drawings without much issue. The difficulty of drawing for me isn't in measuring or line placement, but in figuring out how the subject could be depicted as a drawing in the first place. I don't have an intuitive understanding of what I'm supposed to be marking with lines, or a clear idea of what process people actually use to draw things. I can also never mentally picture what a drawing of any particular subject would look like. As such, there's very little actually guiding my efforts, which is presumably why I always end up with bizarre indecipherable scribbles.

>>6367712
I had similar problem, but I generally solve it in the canvas, and I let fuck ups ignite more ideas, if I can't picture it, time to look at refs and do some iterations. A good exercise is picking an object like a banana, observe it for a minute, notice the contours, textures, distinctive shapes, now get rid of the banana and draw it as you recall, take your time. Now a copy of it now, check the differences between the 2 drawings.

Some cheap workaround for coming up with something is creating a square in an isometric angle, and just put stuff some simple subjects in it, or you can do it with wonky perspective, but keep a basic angle of view, use your room as reference if you want. Like looking at your desk and pretend that's a little village you're looking at. If you're autistic you can make dioramas too. Also try sculpting, even plastiline is good enough, it's just to start to get you thinking spatially, you need to develop that awareness to think above just abstract lines into a white void, if you need an extra push rely on reference for ideas and details.
Even for awareness you need awareness, it's not just about aping things, but being present, if you have different perspectives you've got yourself better odds at solving problems in your art process.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
The only "masteries" are

>line quality

>Perspective

>Anatomy

>Values


Line quality is the best to learn first, deciding what's thick and what's thin, using lines to imply the shape instead of perfectly tracing it out. Anatomy is next, its just measurements. The head is as complex as the entire body, but the key is consistency. Perspective is being able to rotate what you drew and draw it in another angle, usually a more interesting one. Values are colors and shading.

There are things like composition which I would call a mastery but its something you can learn the entire time.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I will translate the OP's chart into words for you autists, with some additional neg levels:

level -2: cant draw lines of any sort , and cannot draw shapes
level -1: can draw lines and simple shapes
level 0: multiple shapes that look human, but fill no 3d space and are not proportional
level 1: proportional and symmetrical
level 2: a minimum understanding of 3d space
level 3: a more complex pose (limited to frontal, 3/4 view, profile)
level 4: Even more complex pose, includes other normal viewing angles - any angle that is not frontal, 3/4, or profile, more subtle control elements.
level 5: Starting to add more extreme perspective control - frogs eye view, birds eye, ants eye, fish eye, perspective and scenery
level 6+: impossible to tell from a single image - history of being "in control of style" with the ability to duplicate/replicate whatever styles the person likes.

Also take the other chart that goes with that one.

yeah, that chart is probs a bit of a rough read for a beg. but a useful concept it outlines is that you can 'level up' different technical drawing skills independently of each other to an extent. whereas in your framework, one might get the impression that any sort of aptitude in one of your levels implies mastery over previous levels.

>>6424819
>>6426198
this anon here (or maybe these are 2 different anons) thinks that their image is at 'level 2 or 3' because it displays a 'minimum understanding of 3d space'. which it actually totally does. but that doesn't mean they've mastered drawing simple shapes, a 'level -1' skill. or that they can draw proportionally or symmetrically, 'level 1'.

the chart outlines that, in reality, you can work on all of these proposed levels at the same time, and depending on your needs and the types of images you wish to draw, focus more on some than others.

pic related is from this artists' twitter who works in a very flat, graphic style:
https://twitter.com/WarwickJC/media
I think a failing of the chart, as well as your own framework, is that they're not able to adequately classify an image like this, clearly pro level work, that isn't leaning on crazy 3d space manipulation or anatomical knowledge.
largely because of the types of images the creator of the graph is interested in drawing: like anime pin ups or whatever. to be fair I think they admit this themselves.
Just useful to let begs know that really strong line and shape confidence, with mastery over proportion, symmetry and other 'low level' skills can lead to a 'pro level' image like the one we see here.
(also, you can see on this guy's twitter that he does have mastery over 3d space, and I'm sure he also has mastery over anatomy and all that figurative good stuff. you can certainly find artists and graphic designers who haven't felt the form, not even once, but have a really strong sense of shape, leading to pro level work. probably not figurative stuff though.)

>>6431321
I don't think you need to focus on any one art fundamental. rather just be conscious of the fact that there's infinite room for growth along any of the art fundamentals, you can always push the horizon.

Right now, it's really not the case that any one of your art fundamentals is significantly stronger than any other, no use putting one on the back burner. you're gonna have to keep focusing on all of them and let a year or so pass before you evaluate strengths and weaknesses again.

You'll need books and courses on perspective, figure drawing, composition. find them in the artbook thread or video course thread, maybe. there should be stuff marked for begs right?
do a very small amount of hoarding, peruse over what you have and start following along with whichever courses seem to produce images similar to ones you'd like to produce right now.
Then it's just a matter of drawing a lot

as for this:
>So basically I should learn how to draw simple shapes (like squares and circles (without perspective) ) and draw things proportionate or symetrical
My advice: put your mind in that of a teenage girl. they're very powerful at drawing hearts and stars and things. because their diaries are full of that stuff, boys names they like wrapped in multiple hearts with arrows and shit flying out of them. and every time they write jason's name they'll try to make the hearts more prettier and have the stars twinkling more pika-pikaly, do you get what I'm saying? consider the sheer tonnage of symmetric shapes they're pumping out and making conscious effort to improve upon. there's no burning out here. there's always another boy on the horizon, and viscerally, they need the hearts to be more symmetric, VISCERALLY. like the need you have to beat off, I'm serious.
so don't break your neck drilling this shit. find chill ways of repeatedly drawing shapes that conform to your own personality. just another instance of finding ways to apply fundies to shit you personally care about.

The biggest thing I suggest is put yourself out there, even if it's only for an artwork dump site. Sure you might not be able to compete with Twitter zoomers but find your niche and what you like to do.

I write this as I am finishing up this gay software boot camp that I started back in March and guess what, I found the perfect junior job without their help anyway.

However I put my mind to said goal and achieved it. You bet your ass when this stupid grind is done in literally 2 weeks to a month that I am picking up my art again and will be even better at fantasy ink art than before and will make my website look more pro as a result.

You have to know "what" you want. If improving your art is one thing, you have to find people willing to be peers or help give tips.

I personally tried a figure drawing sit-down class (no instruction) and had fun with it for one session. However the one guy there told me that the art museum in my area ALSO offers similar courses with instruction.

Guess who's going to sign up for that course? This guy.

But I wouldn't have known if I didn't try to find out myself. I don't even care if it ends up with me finding out that they're copying from some specific anatomy book. Sometimes you gotta have someone teach you how to drive (get your license etc) and then go on a road trip to figure out to really push your car.

Anyway hope this helps. I've been in a similar slump recently and am culling my art webpage to just feature my best work yet for motivation and only scan the good stuff going forward.

>>6428011
>>6428065
Same Anon. You asked for practice.

Sure you can grind out shapes and perspective which is good too. But no one wants to see that either so if you're going to do that, just literally draw circles or shapes for a small bit like a warmup, and focus on particular aspects of art that you want to explore.

I see it like this. Like it or not, video content is worth gold sometimes. So find a decent video that shows the basics of whatever topic you want to check out.

Skim it, and see if it's worthwhile. If so, check it out. Afterwards, pause it at certain points and draw along.

Then, try to figure out another fun approach to grinding out the subject.

For example, weird perspective to me is really cool. However if I need to drill in on the basics, I then kind of play around with midevil town houses or towers etc, meanwhile still treating it as a perspective idea --> "How can I make this castle look different from various angles?" Followed by "damn, this is weird, I wonder what it would take to solve this drawbridge problem. The bridge itself looks like a box too (rectangle), maybe I can find something where perspective rules help with boxes coming towards me. I think one of these books has that solution to that problem"

*proceeds to skim current perspective books, finds similar approach, tries books method, and tries applying it.

Anyway you get the idea. Treat it like a "Choose your own adventure" book.

I will admit, certain things like anatomy and face stuff is hard, and just something you gotta grind to get good at. In this vein, some of those art YouTubers are right with their "100 faces challenges". Reason being is that after you're done making 100 faces, especially just drawn ones from Google images, you will probably understand how to do it a bit better.

Anyway, make sure to have a slight plan with "what to study" but don't grind too hard

I have burned out a few times in my life with hobbies this way, and it's ok to take breaks sometimes.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6428011
besides standard fundieshit that you will find in every beginner reference book it basically comes down to 3 things:
>building knowledge
>building coordination
>training your eyes
the most efficient way to practice all three at once is to draw from life. you can start with simple objects that you find lying around and then work your way up to more complex scenes. you can buy casts & figures once you start wanting to get into drawing people. you can also go to live model sessions if those are available in your area, if not, just draw outside (desu you should do that anyway)
>To become great/pro or even int level would require years if not decades to achieve.
you can reach what a normalfag would consider to be 'pro' and even the crabbiest shitters on this board would consider to be /int/ in 1-2 years of dedicated study. ateliers are full of people who did this. it is not necessarily the most 'fun' learning method though.
what ultimately ends up differentiating a renderbot from a pro comes down to developing secondary skills eg; style, composition, narrative. those are the things that take decades to develop

my personal advice would be to stay the fuck away from twitter, twitterfags and social media culture in general, narrow your focus to specific areas and try to put all your energy into learning them instead of being lead in 50 different directions based on whatever shit the algorithm has decided to throw at you.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>6428011
>set aside 30 minutes to an hour before you start drawing what you want to draw
>pick up literally any how to draw book or tutorial
>pick a page/chapter
>draw what it is about to teach you beforehand (say, a face) without referencing or even with the book open
>once done, READ THE PAGE OR CHAPTER YOU ARE ABOUT TO DRAW FROM FIRST
>now copy 1 for 1, even writing down the labels/guides for things on example images (like the names of muscles, how many head lengths, etc) literally trace if you can/want. trace every little detail. be fucking meticulous about it
>now (with the book still open but not using it to trace) draw what it is teaching you on/in that page/chapter
>repeat once a day until book is finished or you wanna move on
congrats you practiced some fundies. if you can help it throw some gestures into there so you don't end up too stiff from hand-copying.

posts.com: If you have been drawing for a long time and have not made progress, then try to analyze all the stages of your learning and find the one that led you to failure. In your case, reading dozens of books or buying expensive courses is not obligatory. Try to find the learning format that you like and that will motivate you. This can range from attending a private art school or taking online lessons with a tutor. Good luck.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
What you're asking about is a separate skill from technicals/fundies and takes a long time of study and practice. It is taught at concept art and industrial design classes.

My suggestion would be to experiment and synthesize any wildly different sources you can find. Analyze successful media and try to find commonalities in the designs.

When doing character design, try to think about the history, society and climate/environment when motivating various details.

Unless you're absolutely clueless, color theory and composition resources should be taken with a grain of salt.

posts.com: How do I get myself to draw full body drawings with gesture, story and detailed background?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6426565
>Think of a story and scene in your mind.
>Try your best to draw that scene from the image in your mind, onto your canvas
>Fail horribly
>Finish said drawing anyways and try to understand what went wrong.
>See how your favorite artists does this, as the reason why you're depressed at your failures is because you've seen better.
>Try again.
>Repeat for 7 years and become professional.
And sometimes that failed attempt will come out looking better than you pictured it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6426565
Why are you like this? Did you let the early praise you got get to your head?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6426570
I have many scenes in my head that I wish to draw, but I'm unable to translate it into the page. Despite being able to SEE it in my head in full clarity, I need references to bring it into the page. But the references I need do not exist. Other artists just draw from imagination. So I'm stuck with busts of funny animals in a void.
Is it really all just mileage?
>>6426572
Yeah probably.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6426588
>Is it really all just mileage?
Yes. As long as you have self awareness that it doesn't look right, you simply try again the second time and Hope you don't fuck up. And you won't, you'll just make other fuck ups, but it'll feel like you're not making progression, but your clogging up holes within your ship (don't worry, you're not on water yet).
Sometimes it's lack of knowledge. This is where your studies come into play. And sometimes it's lack of direction. This is where your inspirations come into play. Otherwise, 80% of it comes from You trial and error with your work.

posts.com: I recently started drawing or trying to learn a little bit more properly. Around 5-6 weeks I'd say. I used to draw as a kid but I never gave it a serious try, I always gave up and never kept at it. A few weeks ago I had a massive need and motivation to draw so I've been keeping at it, doing a little bit of gesture drawing, form drawing, poses, breaking down body parts/references into smaller parts and trying to understand them. I'm doing a lot of quick drawings from quick poses and after that having fun drawing characters I like I want to get more volume in, have more mental "references". At the end of the day generic cute anime girls are my main motivation to draw(not everything), but I want to get better, I want to be able to do what I want.

>>6411492
Depends on where you’re at, skill-wise and what your goals are. But in order from when I started to now, some books I’ve found helpful are:
Vilppu drawing manual, along with the video lectures
Simultaneously, The first 10-20 pages of any book on perspective to give you a rough idea of 1,2 ,3 point perspective to aid you in the goal of drawing boxes using intuition.
Hampton
Anatomy for sculptors
That Tom fox anatomy book is pretty cool.
And lots of copying art from your favourite artists. And lots of figure drawing.

Experiment with alpha lock, clipping masks, and airbrushes. Start with a low opacity and build up the gradients, um, well, gradually. The image reference has very soft lighting. Work back to front.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6407650
Start with building blocks using a very large brush, then slowly add details and soften the shadows. Also be wary of the perspective

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6407669
well, in digital mediums, it means putting your flats (i.e. solid colors) on the bottom layer and then setting a multiply layer above it for the shadows, and then yet another layer above THAT for the highlights. convert the image to grayscale and try working in value. you don't have to do it that way, but that's a common non-destructive workflow.

basically you want to start with a strong silhouette to use as a clipping mask. if your software has alpha lock, it will do more or less the same thing as a mask. procreate, for example, has this feature. then you want to airbrush within the confines of that silhouette. it's really easier than it sounds.

a sphere is a great place to begin. use the shape tool to create a circle, fill it in, and then use alpha lock so that you're ONLY affecting pixels that are not transparent (i.e. the filled-in circle)

god speed and good luck

posts.com:
>>6402392
comparing your art to the one you have sent i have a few things i would point out.

It looks like you have a grasp on "hue shifting", but there's also something else to consider when it comes to color and that is value. How light or dark something is on your screen.
there are two ways to check your value:
1. if you are on windows, you can assign color modes to your screen. One of them is monochrome. I have this set to a hot key (something like c+shift+windows?) do i can switch back and forth with ease.
2. fill a layer above your whole work with white. set it to "saturation". turn it on when you want to see your values.

If you want your art to have the vibe of the art that you sent, try matching the skin values to that one. You'll see that there is a large range from white to black

Second, try a smaller brush size. Your lines are much thicker than the art that you have sent.

my only other advice to give is.. hwve you studied color theory yet? It comes naturally to some people, but if it hasn't for you, I'd try one of those tumblr era color pallete challenges where you only use the 5-6 colors in a pallete that you like. Over time, it will come naturally. I still copy colors from existing pieces, because some times it helps when i have no clue what to do for the colors.

posts.com:
>>6403190
>>6403270
Just steal the colors of whatever it is you are studying with the picker tool. Anime tends to be very saturated so until you get a feel for recognizing how to pick the colors yourself in your program of choice without cheating, you can do that. Personally I tend to underestimate how saturated something is when I pick colors. Another thing that might throw you off is working on a white background. I usually do lineart and coloring on top of a very light cool gray (contrasts with skin well and is easier on eyes, and even traditional paper is never pure white due to lighting), and you can leave it that way until you're done assuming it's just a figure floating in a void.

that pic I posted was a bad example for your artstyle, it doesn't and shouldn't have so much detail, but I think if you were to use the exact same techniques but with a different brush you'd get a better (imo) result than using the hard round bush, because then you're edges look rounded and bubbly which doesn't suit hair, while a simple, textured brush can do most if not all the work for you. on another note, having every "clump" of hair" of the same size with little variation can also look a bit plasticky, it's good to use the small/medium/large rule and have some variation of the shape itself too

nta but it's just too simple and quick for us to give you any viable feedback. there's no definition to anything and looks as plain as can be. give us your goals and maybe a sheet of 5-6 figure studies and we can help. it's a little lazy to spend about 5 minutes on something and then ask for some vague advice "for improvement". put effort into your work, we'll put effort into the crits. and always mention what you want specific crits on. for your figures; do anatomy studies and ways to make them more interesting than blobs. study foreshortening with overlapping lines, do quick gesture studies alongside the more developed anatomy studies so you can learn to counterbalance your poses, add rhythm, make your figures more interesting.

>what's your process
I try to visualize, then I draw what I see through a series of loose sketches. Then I set transparency to 15% and draw over it a few times with each iteration looking closer and closer to my ideal. Sometimes it works and sometimes I need to pull up refs. Sometimes that also doesn't work then I just give up and sulk.

>>6425531
Yes, the turning of the waist to the bottom area. I don't have reference but I'm pretty sure the body can't do that, you'd have to modify the angle ot the torso and maybe add something else like her legs resting on a bed or something like that to justify it, but it's mainly on how you can see her butt cheeks on all its planes when holding that pose, in reality you'd see half of that round shape, that obviously alters the angles of the leg as well, and so does it's pose, and don't confuse it with perspective, you being higher on the camera doesn't mean you'd see it all, this is a anatomical problem mainly, it's a good idea to do a few thumbnails for these kind of poses before jumping into a final, it's not necessarily too difficult of a pose, but it'll save you time later.
Also, her face is really good, lots of personality in it.

>>6432553
This one would look good with a light/shadow area, right now it's fully in shadow, add some light source maybe on her face and it'll pop out more, but looking it closer it seems it had a light source, but it's not clear and looks like shadow, always make the disctintion so you don't get your halftones or reflected lights mixed up, otherwise you'll image will become flat.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6432553
I used levels on the image, just to adjust the values a bit, didn't go too far but you could squeeze out the light and shadow difference more if you wanted, it messes with the saturation and colors though, using the color balance menu helps too, I'd advice checking a tutorial about it because you can actually fiddle with some color ranges using the hand icon and sampling from the image directly.
I added a simple gradient to frame it, it's a cheap trick, but obviously you could do more than this and your actual piece would require some previous planing and careful value/color choice before jumping into color blending or layer adjustments, it helps but it won't do the job for you.

XP-Pen is another alternative, but their color/contrast isn't as good as huion's, and most of their tablets use an antiglare film instead of etched glass.

If you want to buy once and cry once, wacom is the industry standard, but will cost you your first born for no noticeable benefit over modern chinkshit.

You could also go for something like an older cintiq 24 from 2012 for about the same price as a modern kamvas 24, but you'll have 10 year old tablet tech which was kinda shit in comparison to what we have now.

We've had qhd 20"+ tablets for years. And no, it's not overkill to have 4k on a drawing tablet that your face is inches from. Qhd on a 24" is only barely higher ppi than 1080p on a 20".

A multitude of reasons I feel are legitimate:
>lack of expandable storage via microSD (I don't stream music, I torrent albums)
>no headphone jack which would force me into bluetooth headphones or Apple proprietary stuff
>browser is limited to Safari if I want extensions, watching Youtube without Ublock and sponsorblock is a joke
>much harder to utilize for downloaded manga/comics than android or windows
>to sideload things that aren't Apple store approved you must jailbreak the device
>no improved Discord with plugins that android has via Aliuwucord

If those are not legitimate downsides for someone who is primarily an android and windows user then I'm curious what else you'd qualify as "blind hate".
I like freedom with my devices and don't normally use mainstream apps. Apple really caters to simplicity first which usually isn't my M.O. I can appreciate they're great for drawing but that doesn't mean it would be my ideal for everything else.

Why You Should Copy Anime:
https://i.imgur.com/zNDsyF0.jpg
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kbKqIJcIUCw
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dgjx6y6B_G8

**Strive for quantity AND quality.**

Anime Studying:
>Copy anime references exactly and draw them from memory. Use illustrations, screenshots, anime figures, 3D models, etc.
>Don’t copy recklessly. Use construction, color theory, and other fundamental concepts to rehearse a drawing process that you can later easily manipulate for original artwork.
>Post all of your anime studies. Post even when you’re told not to. Create an art community that actually draws and improves together instead of just talking about it.
>Number your attempts and link to your previous posts.
>Critiquers should lead by example by posting their studies.

General Anime Style Discussion:
>Questions about achieving certain styles/techniques/compositions etc.
>Drawing methods, study habits, resources, tutorials, tools, software, etc
>Be specific and try to post a sample of your study attempts before asking for help.

**Draw copies from good anime styled references to mindfully up our mileage, internalize appealing aesthetics, and learn from each other’s processes and knowledge.**

Recommended Resources:
https://pastebin.com/Yz2scAEc

>>>/ic/mmg

Just have bare minimum measuring knowledge and in theory that should be all.
https://www.dorian-iten.com/howtodraw/
Being able to understand 3D form and perspective helps a lot with actually understanding what you're copying, but don't get stuck filling pages with boxes when all you want to do is draw cartoon characters.
The Art & Science of Drawing has a good intro to drawing volumetrically and covers measuring too. But that's all supplementary, as soon as you understand how to copy there's no reason not to start right away.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6426634
Not at all. You need to have marks down so you have a point of comparison. Here's a video of one of Krenz's students copying simple line drawings:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iK5Qn_Iwv9A
Accuracy, specially as a beginner, isn't about getting things exactly right the first time, but being patient and correcting things until you do. With time your eye for proportions and relative distances will get better, but even pros have to double-check and correct their initial assumptions from time to time.

As long as you're actually comparing the distances and measuring you'll get something out of it. In real life people have to be more thoughtful about checking since it takes way longer to do, but in both cases comparing with the original is the only way to know if you have the "right answer".
It might be a good idea to only check once you're done with a stage of blocking-in, and then correct as needed until you can move on. If you check after every line or every other line it really would be pretty close to mindless.
Being ambitious is a good attitude, the upper half looks very nice. If you combine accuracy with studying volumetric drawing you can understand the subject better and get more out of artist studies.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>6426949
I just mean drawing with 3D volume in mind. The folds on the sleeves, for example, come across as random marks and don't have any form.
Depicting form with only line is very difficult, but things don't suddenly flatten out when they're in frontal or side view. Seeing how others can create the illusion of volume even under those constraints is one of the reasons to do master studies.
Training accuracy is mostly about 2D observations like relative proportion, but if you're studying an image that depicts 3D form you'll miss out on a lot if you don't keep those aspects in mind and analyse them too.

>>6428305
Chicken scratching just means drawing a billion little lines to build up one hard to read, hairy-looking line. This is bad because it makes the drawing confusing even to the person who drew it, and fucks up your perception making it harder to see the form.
Restating a line to refine a shape or guessing what you want your composition or pose to be with light lines before committing to a darker one is regular sketching behaviour and an extremely common way of drawing.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I don't want to seem overly critical, but I feel that the standard way to draw anime is a bit misguided.

Those early animations from which anime is derived were worked on by talented illustrators and painters. But the reason why their output was relatively extremely simplistic wasn't because they didn't desire accurate paintings, but because it would have taken a hundred years to make every frame realistic.

The lineart-and-bucket-fill method was not the desired outcome, but was the most efficient way to drop down shape and definition. If you are not aiming for that one-frame-a-minute pace, I think it would be better to paint your anime, than to draw it.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>6430997
It's hard to present a thesis when you have a 1000 character limit.

It was merely an observation from doing some research on old animation stuff that the vast majority of anime ever made was made by simplifying a complex subject, outlining the simplification, and filling color inside the lines. This style was a necessity because of time and money constraints, and is the source of "Anime style".

This contrasts with what I've seen recommended for "How to draw Anime", where they tell you to do overly complex style-copying or construction on your favorite anime, when that isn't likely how the original artist made it, or how the original artist would have preferred to make it.

This was not meant to be an attack on others' preferred methods of making art. I just thought it overly complicated.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6431107
Are you telling /beg/s to freehand their drawings because that's what professionals do?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6431107
>This style was a necessity because of time and money constraints, and is the source of "Anime style".
Anime isn't the only medium which does that. Manga, comics, bandes dessinés, etc also do.
This end result doesn't look as such solely due to process behind, it's also due to it being an efficient way to convey meaning and incite emotions in the viewers in an artistic and archetypal manner which can resonate with our brains in way reality/realism cannot, I think. As in, less details isn't entirely about making the work easier, it's also about getting to the essence of things more straightforwardly.

>This contrasts with what I've seen recommended for "How to draw Anime", where they tell you to do overly complex style-copying or construction on your favorite anime, when that isn't likely how the original artist made it, or how the original artist would have preferred to make it.
That's an interesting remark. For that I think we need to study the kind of people who tend to try and replicate things in such a thorough manner and get why they do so.
The original artist doesn't make it as such because it's innate to them, it's what the different parts of their mind end up producing altogether.
For someone trying to copy it stems from them feeling like what they see is what they want to ingrain. It's like a mirror image which mirrors some sort of sum of what they internally value, or getting close to it at least. Such people who are very sensitive to this internal process have a hard time letting lose and drawing something they internally value negatively since the result they see ends up being linked to their self-worth, which is discouraging. So to sprout motivation they end up making these "overly complex style-copying/construction" in order to slowly rewrite this physical habit within themselves in a way which feels good to them.
Eventually they'll be able simplify the construction the more the target style is "achieved" (cont)

>>6428944
>I just keep jumping from book to book everytime I can't copy the illustrations and I'm losing my mind
That’s kind of the heart of the problem, isn’t it? It honestly doesn’t really matter what resource you pick to learn from as long as you consistently work through the material and don’t just jump ship if you don’t get it right at first. Failure is an inherent part of learning so your best bet is to just power through the failures until you succeed.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6428944
Just do Bargue plates. It's slow and tedious busywork but it'll teach you relative measuring and train your eye so you can catch your mistakes more easily and play spot the difference between your study and the original better.
Don't binge the whole thing, just a bit everyday. It's fucking boring but it works, and once you have a good eye for proportions and accuracy studying is easier.
You actually plateau pretty fast when only drawing as a hobby with little to no studying like most people did as children/teens. Deliberate practice is the only way anyone improves, but if you don't draw for fun and don't mix studying with drawing what you like you'll be miserable and burn out.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6428944
if you're having eyeballing issues, try practicing with graph paper and overlaying a grid on your reference to match and have it side by side to match. instead of tackling an overwhelming amount of detail at once, you break it down by matching the lines/details on the smaller squares.

pic related. it should help your sanity a bit since you'll see progress as long as you're autistic about the accuracy of the line placements in the squares.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6428960
That sounds like a nice, good practice
Thank you! I'll keep it in mind

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6428973
no problem. as you advance you can enlarge those squares until eventually it's 4x4 or none at all. the key is to be super autistic about line placement to train your accuracy. good luck.

When you owe your stock broker money and don't have the cash to cover your ass, they force you to sell some of your stuff to settle the balance. Rich people don't usually have billions of dollars in cash lying around, they take out a loan against the stock that they own and use that to pay for expenses. If the price of the stock they put up for collateral drops, it's possible that the amount they owe the bank could be larger than the amount of credit the bank extended, in which case, they force sell the stock, further lowering the amount of collateral and potentially creating a vicious cycle.

>>6419129
Beginner because there are significant errors in perspective, anatomy, and line work, and very little attempt at rendering. By significant errors, I mean the following. Perspective: the hat seems to be intended to be circular and viewed from below, and if that is the case, we should see most of the underside, but instead we see most of the top. Anatomy: the left and right hands have different finger widths and the right hand could not grip the pole properly in this position. Also there is no shape to the ankles, and a very long torso and upper legs compared to short lower legs. Line work: the line work is all of the same width and is concentrated in areas of higher detail, making them appear darker even when they are not in shadow. Hatching direction is inconsistent without any obvious reason to change directions in different areas. Rendering: the light seems to be coming from the left according to the fence and the clouds, but the grass casts shadows in the opposite direction - unless those are ripples, which is unclear. Some portions of the character are shaded, while the hands, face, and underside of the hat are not shaded. The transition from light to dark is abrupt in all areas without any form of feathering.

That said, the composition is nice and I like the way that the fishing rod and line bounces the eye back and forth. The face also looks appealing. This is a beginner with potential.

>>6419297
Intermediate. There is still room for technical improvement as always - for example, the position of the feet in the middle left image is unnatural - but the errors aren’t glaring. You have enough mastery of the basics that you no longer have to think so much about anatomy, perspective, etc. and can start to focus on finding your personal style and/or the types of subjects and ideas you want to explore, perhaps via multiple styles. I see an exploration of many styles and subjects here, which is great. If you’re in the concept art field, this is a decent portfolio. But each one looks mass produced. Joker smile, big boobs, etc. If you want to rise above being a decently hirable concept artist in a very competitive market, push for more originality and more depth to your subject matter. Also, keep working your technical details.

Yes, I was in the exhibitor hall for that con. Pretty much every artist there filed a complaint about it in the feedback for next year. I doubt they'll be allowed back since AX actually has a committee that has a file on every exhibitor and they will review their file and cancel booths that have demerits.

There was actually ANOTHER AI booth too, like 2 booths over. They were a maid cafe that had some AI prints of their maids done in addition to photos of their cosplay maids. Because the first one was so blatant nobody noticed the maid cafe one so they got away with it.

AI is pretty much getting blacklisted at conventions going forward. They're pretty pro-artist generally, as the Artist Alley heads are often run by former artists or friends of artists. People routinely get blacklisted from them for doing things that get people pissed off on social media or pissing someone in the Artist Alley staff off.

Sakimichan is permanently banned from Anime-North (the biggest convention in Canada) for trying to get around the no-fanart policy in exhibitors back in 2018 by buying a table to advertise her own convention, (Sakimicon) selling VIP package tickets there which allowed them to pick a bunch of prints.

>assuming I'm good enough to do prints

The print market is pretty competitive, so a lot of the artists there with lower tier art do small merch like charms/stickers/pins/pillows. I know a few artists that sell very little prints but still make 10k+ just by doing small merch.

Small merch is all chibis so you don't need that high of an art skill to do, just need to find a cute style. You do need a lot of coverage though, since each individual item is cheaper you need to sell a lot more to a single person, so having all their waifus/husbandos available with a nice bundle discount is optimium.

>>6432029
set your pressure to soft or you will kill your hands.

curving to the upper left is soft feeling, less pressing needed to activate the whole range, but lower pressure accuracy;

curving to the lower right is hard, more pressing needed to activate the whole range, but more fine control over the range. trying to hit the high end of the range requires a lot of force that when repeated will eventually lead to various sorts of RSI

posts.name: Anonymous

>>6432029
It's not something easy to tell. Pressure settings all depends on how hard you like to press on your pencil, what tablet you got and the brush you are using.
If you feel something is wrong then it probably is. Just tweak your settings until you find something nice.

I personally don't like to press hard and here are my settings. There is no need for big brushes, 4 to 15px are enough for my regular sketches and linearts. If I want a thinner line I use a smaller brush, and vice versa. Much like in real life.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6432270
Here's a solution. Get a real a marker or a pigma color, test how you handle the pressure from soft to hard and see how it reflects on paper, hold that thought on your head and see how you translate that on a digital painting software with an ink or marker brush, are you okay with the pressure transition? too hard? lower it, too snappy? extended the curve to the right. Do it until you're happy with it.
What some other artist does doesn't really matter, it's not giving you real pen pressure feedback about it, you're juding based on the quality of his lineart, not the pressure itself, you're not going to magically turn into a chinese lineart master fiddling with the settings, you actually have to stick with a handful of brushes, practice them until you understand its advantages/quirks, and put them through a stress test, which is just drawing whatever you want, that's how people choose their brushes, some are jack of all trades, some only work for one specific thing, pick a generic lineart brush and a painting brush and try to learn them fully, when they feel too limiting, try a new one.
Basically this a (You) solution, no one can tell you what good feels like other than explaining what the pressure setting does and how that affects your hand and tablet, which has already been done, the mastery of the pressure and brush is either the artist already knowing how those brushes work irl and translating that information accurately into a digital medium so it's not working against you or what you already know, even if you started digital and never did trad you'll have to know what your hand and grip is best suited for.
Last, if you want to start with a brush that is fool proof, or at least doesn't excuse you for it looking bad/wrong, just download brush packs that are already rated by artists. You can find some on places like deviantart or here in threads like the CSP one. For PS kyle webster brushes are a safe choice, search in gumroad too.

Conclusion: the best software is as stable as Clipstudio with as many features as Krita the stabilizer of Firealpaca and the brush palette and performance of SAI. In other words it doesn't fucking exist. They all suck in one way or another.
The solution is to use multiple software. Sketch in SAI or Firealpaca, ink and color in Clipstudio, then do post-processing in Krita.

posts.sub: How do you study from books
posts.com:
I've been filted by all books about drawing I've read.
How does one approach them?
Do you copy the drawings it has? Memorize them? Read then and then try to do it? Doing it while reading it? Using it in real life?

How do you process the information in the books?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6410740
1. Make a google document with the name of the subject matter, then the book and teacher's name
2. Write down an explanation of which fundamental the book teaches, why I need to learn it and what my goals wiht it are
3. Divide the book/seminar in weeks or chapters.
4. Read 1 Chapter, write down my own understanding of it in the google document
5. Finish off by giving myself homework on it, and take a snap shot to paste it into said google document
6. Move onto the next chapter and repeat

This is the best way to actually learn on your own, you only truly understand things when you are forced to explain them to yourself in written form, then you are forced to apply it.
-
I am actually doing this exact same thing with that book you just posted. I have to do 100 figures, I got 10 down so far. I gave myself an explanation of the core ideas, from the 8 parts of the body to the rythm, story, balance, weight, CSI lines and the metholodgy applied step by step (Finding the head, then the spine, then into the pelvis using repetition lines that add flow and gesture to it, before placing wrapping lines).
posts.filename: Michael Hampton - Anatomy - Homework 1 - 100 Figure Drawings

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6410743
How do you figure out what's the best homework for every chapter?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6410744
With that book specifically, its ez because Michael Hampton as a seminar that literally tells you what the homework should be

But as a rule of thumb, you are going to want to draw a shit lot of whatever they actually tried to explain in said chapter.
So, if the chapter is about learning how to use the multiplication/division technique to extend squares as they recede back into space, then you do that exercise 50 times till it becomes ez
If the chapter is about how to render a sphere, then you go and render 100 spheres from as many angles as you can imagine/find in refs

If you are looking for Michael Hamptons homework I can give it to you :o

Here is the homework either way :o


----------------------------------------
Course Description:
As students continue to develop a basic skill set throughout this course, a special emphasis will be placed on the understanding and application of those basics to the human figure. This course will emphasize a process based approach and development of the figure heavy in an analysis of from, construction, and perspective. This course will offer and in depth study of the figure and the surface anatomy while always maintaining a grounding in the artistic and principles of design.
Week 1: Lecture: Introduction of teacher/ Goals of class. Lecture on gesture and the development of a process.

Homework: 100 Gesture Drawings (half should be done from life, the other half from Old Masters drawings, paintings or sculpture). Choose 5 of your best gestures to submit for critique and instructor feedback. Drawings may be scanned in and submitted or submitted as digital files done in photoshop or as jpgs. You may also upload one, or more, for student feedback on the class blog.
Week 2: Lecture: Connections, Shape and Understanding the skeletal landmarks.
Homework: 25 construction drawings. Drawings should follow in class process of gesture, shapes, connections, landmarks, and finally into a development of the perspectives of the torso, arms, and legs. Choose 2-5 of your best to submit for critique and instructor feedback.
Week 3: Lecture: Head Drawing. Construction and design of the human head.
Homework: 25 Head constructions. Following the in class work flow, develop the head from simple shapes into the architectural planes. Development of the features is optional. Choose 2-5 of your best to submit for critique and instructor feedback
----

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6410753
Week 4: Lecture: Muscles: Torso/trunk. Placing the anatomical shapes of the upper and lower torso based off the understanding of the skeletal landmarks.
Homework: 25 Construction drawing with the anatomy of the upper and lower torso included on top. Only develop the muscles covered within the lecture, but be sure to draw the entire pose. Choose 2-5 of your best to submit for critique and instructor feedback.
Week 5: Lecture: Torso 2.
Homework: 25 Construction drawing with the anatomy of the upper and lower torso included on top. Include the muscles discussed in the prior week as well as the anatomy of the torso. Choose 2-5 of your best to submit for critique and instructor feedback.
Week 6: Lecture: Structure and anatomy of the legs
Homework: 25 Leg and pelvis constructions. Include the anatomy on top of the underlying skeletal and perspective breakdowns. Pay close attention to the shape, gesture, and perspective of each shape as you build. Choose 2-5 of your best to submit for critique and instructor feedback.
Week 7: Lecture: The structure, design and anatomy of the upper arm and shoulders.
Homework: 25 Shoulder and arms constructions. Develop the anatomy of the upper arms together with the anatomy of the upper torso. This week should specifically focus on the shoulder girdle and the muscles of the scapula and front of the humerus. Choose 2-5 of your best to submit for critique and instructor feedback.
Week 8: Lecture: The structure, construction, and design of the forearm.
Homework: 25 Shoulder and arms constructions. Develop the anatomy of the upper arms together with the anatomy of the forearms. Choose 2 of your best to submit for critique and instructor feedback.
---------------------

Thats all of it, save it into a notepad or something :o

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6410740
Level 1, copy the drawings. You don't have to copy everything, but copy the stuff that kind of makes sense to you and appeals to you. Try to think of the forms he is conveying instead of copying lines.

Level 2, Draw from reference photos in the style of the book. Look at both the reference and the book. Make sure that the poses are not too difficult or not too different from what is in the book to keep it simple.

Level 3, Try to make small adjustments to the drawings in the book. Nothing too crazy, just small changes, but this time you have only the Hampton book to look at, no reference photos.

Level 4, Draw from reference photos in the constructive manner of Hampton, but this time you put the book away. See what you remember. Use the book after to fill in the gaps. This is a good moment to revert to level 1 and copy the drawings. Note how you copy them more freely and with more understanding.

Level 5, Create simplified Figures in the style of the book from imagination. Don't go too crazy at first with the poses. Start with generic and easy poses. You will quickly find out which areas you have to revisit.


Don't worry if you are stuck at the early levels for very long, maybe even years. The key is to find a healthy daily drawing habit aside from studying books. Someone who sketches random stuff around the house daily or just draws cute girls for fun everyday, will have a much easier time going through a book like that. Try to be that person first.

posts.com:
Resolution thread. What size canvas do you paint with and what is the best resolution to print digital art? How does one go about choosing the best canvas size?
If I want to be able to print in a A0 format max, will a 9000px (ish) canvas do it? Will I be able to scale it down without losing too much quality if afterwards I want to print in a smaller format?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6429385
DPI is most important when looking at print. Usually 300 will suffice but 600 dpi I hear is used for large posters.

Canvas size is dependent on what you're doing. Sketching you can away with anything where you don't see pixelations. Any kind of line work I'd recommend at least 4000 if not 6000.

Painting I'd cater to your hardware. You can always start small at like 1000 and gradually scale up as you add details. You don't want to start large since if you start using huge brushes on a 5000 size canvas, your hardware may lag. But its ultimately what your hardware can handle.

posts.com: when do you save as .jpg or .png?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6413358
.png for images in black and white or very few colors, .jpg for paintings.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6413358
If file size isn't an issue .png is preferable since PNGs are have lossless compression unlike JPGs. This effectively means if a .jpg is opened and edited multiple times it loses information and degrades in quality.

The reason you would choose .jpg over .png for paintings or coloured work is because of printing, which may not be relevant to your needs. The reason for this is .png is in RGB not in CMYK which is what's used in printing so there is a risk of discrepancy with the colour. There are other ways to address this besides using .jpg and it's very situational, so overall I would still say .png the preferable choice.

posts.com:
please explain these in terms so that a retard can understand
>form
>values
>gesture

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6416834
>form
Making a 2d image look 3d by applying perspective.

>value
in the absolute dumbest terms, it indicates a plane change and/or allows the viewer to separate objects from another. See the example. If all the squares were black, it would look like one shape instead of 3 separate shapes. On a single cube, it would indicate the direction the light source.

>gesture
Difficult to understand unless you have some semblance of form. If you combine all of the small shapes of a figure into one large shape, the gesture is essentially the "motion" or curve the large shape is making. Usually this is one big curve called the "line of action" and doesn't necessarily only apply to figure drawing.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6420642 >>6420663
Ok... This is really complicated. I have made hours and coutless of tests about this. The main problem is that the image color profile goes through layers and layers of softwares.

It's all messed up. For instance:
1) The new photo viewer of Windows manages colors in a different way from the old one, which is still installed in the system.
2) A program like CSP does not use color management (you can use the color proof, but the color picker will be wrong).
3) On Windows you can add the color profiles as "advanced color profile", but no one knows what it does because there is not a documentation about it (avoid this setting).

The more I test stuff, the more I get headache. I have just setted everything as sRGB IEC61966-2.1, and when I save the image, I save it without embedding the color profile and coverting it to sRGB (the coversion should be useless because I worked already in sRGB color space). I'm sorry that I can't really answer.

Also, an unrelated thing. Stuff about color proof in grayscale and gamma.
https://gregbenzphotography.com/luminosity-masking/how-to-optimize-your-gray-working-space-for-better-luminosity-masks/
https://youtu.be/tkAW9u2fZGY

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6423798
vanishing points with enclosed scenes are kind of tricky. if they're far enough you can kind of estimate them without much issue. if you work in digital you can zoom out quite far and add guidelines, but i'm not sure how practical it'd be in traditional.
what i find helpful, is often things will share horizon lines. for example, if you wanted to rotate an object that's otherwise in a one point perspective scene, the point itself would be in a different place, but it'd share it's horizon with that first point (i visualise this as it sliding along the horizon line). if it was rotated vertically, i'm not sure if there's a vertical equivalent to a horizon, but you'd essentially do the same thing above/below the "main" vanishing point.
it being rotated both horizontally and vertically starts to get a bit complicated. if you're struggling with perspective, don't worry about this for now
a character or figure would generally share it's vanishing point with the scene, but it depends. as it's more organic and rounded vs a cube or object, i wouldn't worry about it too much as long as the horizon/viewpoint looks okay and is generally consistent with the rest of the scene. the other anon's suggestion about drawing them in a box can be helpful to get a feel for it/keep them in scale.
i think this can be hard to visualise with text alone, lmk if you need any clarification or examples and good luck

In english, crayon means a stick of chalk or wax. Like picrel.
In French, it means "pencil". Think regular pencil.

Looking at this drawing, it looks like it was made using wax pastels (close to picrel too). Fancy art shop will have dry pastels and wax pastels. Personally, I prefer the wax ones, the dry ones are closer to colored charcoals. You can also mix the two!
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Crayon
Hope you have fun with trad drawing, anon.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6423798
Just imagine enclosed scenes as if you're inside a "box", logically if the structure has right angles it converges somewhere in the horizon line, if you need visualize it, instead of working on an enclosed canvas, create a frame for your piece, then create this big box in 2pp that expands outside of the frame, you'll have already decided where your eye level or horizon line is, then just place each vanishing point where you want them to be, this is for your box, and any other object that aligns with said box.
Basically, your creating a box where things are going to sit, then you'll play camera man and adjust what you want to show on the plane. You can freehand it first then do a small/medium sketch with accurate perspective then blow it up in whatever size you're actually doing the painting. A common mistake for people doing perspective is they start big and go straight at it without any idea at the blank page, from experience it simply doesn't work and you'll get frustrated and will end up rushing it/stopping.
Perspective drawings are harder because they deal with more elements in the plane, so you'll you have to break it down in steps, plan your painting, get some dirty small sketches out first, if you're doing it trad they can be 5x7 cm, in digital something like 640x480 will do, you can use a big canvas and create a few squares for these sketches, you'll have room for the box process (you may end up not doing this anymore in the future, but it has a few other uses anyway) and you'll be doing different iterations right there, and you can get them out quick. Using reference is also suggested, just don't go blind expecting to create a final result right off the bat if you have no mental image or an idea of how things actually look like.
Also watch Vandruff's 1994 perspective lectures, it deals with different kind of measurement systems that may be useful for you, like projecting measurements on space based on translating divisions from 2D measurements.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6424704
Don't ctrl+Z too much. A "correct" line isn't necessarily a good one.
I don't know if that's your case, but drawing lines very timorously like you're performing open heart surgery is generally what makes them feel dead. If you zoom in on a high res versions of drawings you like, you'll probably find a lot more overlaps and small gaps than you would've thought.
That's not to say you should be careless, just that you shouldn't sacrifice what looks good for what you think would be proper.
If you have trouble getting out of the mindset of just tracing the sketch try lowering the opacity more, gaussian blurring it, or changing the colour if you don't do that already.

posts.com:
>>6425667
The following can be done over a month, less if you're dedicated

Learn how to use a ruler to measure things
Learn how to draw lines accurately by practicing various line control exercises
Draw circles, lots of circles.

Draw cubes, lots of cubes in various orientations

Learn to construct using directional shapes such as teardrops and semicircles. Just draw a fuckton of teardrops and semicircles touching, overlapping, etc. to build up random forms.

Using art you like as a ref, build up forms with the prior method to reconstruct the general body shapes and so on. Do the same with individual parts like hands.

Trace art you like to learn how they do their lineart.

Ethan becker has some good videos that you can kind of understand better when you hit this point.

>>6428378
squats, bench press, overhead press, row, deadlift

pick a weight you can barely do 7 times for everything but deadlift, 5 for deadlift

lift for 10 sets, try to do 10 reps

the moment you can do 10 reps for 5 sets add weight till you can barely lift 7 times, repeat till this process no longer works

with deadlifts, you want to go for a weight you can do but not do it so much you let form die to exhaustion.

you could replace deadlift with good mornings, and squats with lunges, there are various other exercises with dumbbells if you don't have a bar bell, and there are ways to do it without weights but that's a complete bitch unless you have perfect form.

this process is for beginner gains, and only works for beginners or if you want to just maintain weight, it focuses entirely on complex motions that involve muscle chains.

once this stops working, you are either going to fall into a strength gain routine, or you will fall into a bodybuilder routine, I suggest bodybuilder over strength due to that's what most people want out of the exercises.

and like everything weight/bodybuilding, diet is more important than the exercise.

this is essentially what the sticky is for anyone new, beyond this is FAR outside the scope of the sticky that it doesn't matter.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6430604
A lot of these "simple" methods of drawing heads still require skills that beginners have not yet mastered, such as drawing rounded shapes correctly and drawing contour lines over a form to suggest its orientation. Most of the challenge is in first learning to see so you can judge your own work and correct it as you go. Try to slow down, work lightly but neatly, and don't move to the next step until the current step actually looks right. You might have watched a video in which an experienced artist moves quickly through the process (possibly augmented by time-lapse video), which gave you an unreasonable expectation of how quickly you'd be able to draw these examples. Start with the assumption that this is a challenging process and deserves more time. "Simple" shapes are not always easy to draw, but it is easier to visualize a plain ovoid than a detailed, completed head on the page before you put down a mark, and easier to judge the correctness of its proportions and placement.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6416749
(Clockwise order)
So-bin
Murata
Atmosphere sketchbooks has sketches from I think 3 artists
Settei Dreams has artbooks and storyboards of anime
Horikoshi has sketches
And Inoue Kiyoshirou has an "artbook" which is just the sketches of a hentai he drew.

In the end, you won't find many "artbooks" like the yoshinari one especially of artists' sketches. Mostly finished work which you said you're not looking for.
Also, don't limit to just artbooks, copy directly from manga too.(Which is how most mangakas got good.) since they're basically just clean sketches

Lastly, don't hoard books, I recommend copying front to back 1 at a time before moving onto the next one every single week.
Hope I helped ;)

you can learn fundamentals like anatomy, construction, and gesture from master copies. It's not just surface technique. Why not give it a try?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6416980
I wasn't suggesting they weren't, I was more wondering if there was something additional I could have in mind when copying.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6416988
Depending on how strong your fundamentals are, it will extend your understanding of them. If you don't know perspective then you can't understand how the artist is playing with perspective. Master studies are typically done to see how a specific artist solved a problem. There is a big difference between how a sculptor solves painting clothing folds and a comic artist and a painter and one or all of them may be compatible with the style you inevitably end up with but you won't know unless you do the studies to begin with.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
This thread is dedicated to master studies, where you copy artwork you admire as a form of study. They are the quickest way to improve and learn about any fundamental you are having problems with. If you need to work on your hands, copy hands from other artists, and if you're having trouble with rendering, make careful studies of paintings with lighting you admire. Studies can be quick or long. You can even copy anatomy books like Bridgman, Morpho, and Hogarth. The type of studies you want to do depend on your personal goals and the types of problems you are grappling with.

Artists of all levels are welcome. Critiques and redlines are encouraged.

Recommended watching:

You mean David Finch? The extra girth makes it easier to hold in general. You can hold it with a more relaxed grip or since it is soft, grip it tight without much strain on your hand. This helps to ease cramping from long sessions. It also makes it a bit easier to control of the tip of the pencil.

if you haven't tried the memorization technique, now would be a good time to try it, especially if you're going for simpler studies like for the features.

Make a study
Put away the reference / previous drawing
Draw it again

This will really help the shapes you are studying in Morpho come out in your imaginative drawing

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: another day of me trying to make rendering a habit again with these 30 min studies

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Insanely hard, took like an hour and a half, and an hour of that was just staring at it. Of course I got the first figure done before I realized it was gonna go off the page. So there are no corrections on this one, I did them after I took the picture because the page would be extremely cluttered. Still, I got more right on the bottom one than I thought I would. I think if you had to memorize one bridgman drawing perfectly, it should be this one. There are so many clues and shorthands about how bridgman constructs and thinks about the figure. I will be revisiting this one for sure.

>>6378026
I have the opposite problem, I took a painting class years ago and can only fix things or add detail by reshaping blobs of "paint". My skills have degraded from absence and I'm playing catchup, but my eyes are still ok. I'd like some help on that, but for your problem:

Usually a person has a preference for what kind of style of painting they want, even if they aren't consciously thinking about a certain era of painting. Here are some things to keep in mind while painting:
Do you like it when it looks like you painted it, or do you want to hide it?
Are little details fun or annoying? How about highlights?
There are many ways to make a focal point, which way do you like?

And when you've figured this out, you bend more towards that direction. Since this is the master study thread, you eyeball the art movements on wikipedia or something and say, "that one". For example, someone who doesn't enjoy painstaking detail and wants a painterly look, but likes little flourishes may study impressionist artists.

>>6385906
I know this was posted a while ago but given how complicated the original seems to be, how did you go about starting this study? I still stumble over my own feet when doing master studies of complex work

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6400090
spend quite some time doing line art
then paint all the big shape first squint my eyes till it has similar value and color contrast (since I don't try to make it the exact color from the rei one)
when both are done the rest is just mindless zooming in and filling/rendering all the small stuff following the line while zooming out to double-check the big picture with rei one
then paint over the line and redraw some of it
notice that rei is using a different technique here with clean line art and sticking to it so the edge is cleaner and can change line art color a lot. which is hard for me to do since the ref is kinda blurry and I'm lazy so I draw loosely then paint over and redraw some of the line art

your corrections look really great, but the memory drawings are a bit rough. That might be a sign you're not constructing strictly enough. i got a question
does a master study need to be a 1:1 copy of the subject?
sometimes it irks and disappoint me in the end when i noticed my whole piece is different from the subject, especially when i notice some lines doesnt match, the angle is off, etc.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6427376
It feels really pedantic at first but you need be able to copy things exactly. When other artists do something successfully, the copying skill will let you figure out how to do it for yourself, so it unlocks a lot of learning to be able to do it right. You are already starting to get the even more important thing though, which is that exact copying forces you to develop your ability to see.

please stop doing this—I don't know why undersized heads are so popular with artists who draw this body type because it's not as if your head shrinks when your body gets heavier. Microcephaly is not a marker of "fertility." The most important things to remember are where the clavicle/shoulders, ribcage, and hips have ended up, because they're all covered now with fat but still determine where masses like the breasts, belly, thighs are going to sit. And knowing where those are will help keep the head proportionate when you are sketching; not knowing I assume is why it shrinks more often than not with these artists.

>>6428073
Because drawabox is dry and soulless as fuck. It will kill your motivation to continue drawing unless you are extremely autistic and can stick through with it.

There's also a huge drawback to being 100% practice 0% fun, and it's that you'll become good at only exercises and copying references for figure drawing and whatnot, but when you finally think of drawing what you always wanted, it will be super intimidating and if you can push past that, it will still look way worse.

Best way to learn is to mix both. Yes, you draw like a kindergartener, but next time you draw like a child, try to incorporate what you have learned so far into it.

Is it actually practical for begs to do bargue plates or is this a clever ruse to get OP to kill himself

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6432052
Probably. The method is just that. You can use tracing paper to check accuracy on your practice paper and that's what most traditional artists had been doing in the past. This method of study is usually called Master study but can be done as soon as you are just a beginner. It builds your ability to draw things correctly, transfering 3d objects onto 2d paper as well as building up your visual library. It's what artist had been doing for hundereds of years and a foolproof method. I know that this is hard when you just start out but be patient and you'll harvest sweet fruits in no time. Keep your way of methodology practice drawing as simple and direct as possible, consume solid knowledge from books written by foolproof professional artists (knowledge heavy based stuff like Color and Light by James Gurney rich visual enhhancement heavy based stuff like Monster Hunter Illustrations book).

See? It will be much more fun and much better than that "modernised revolutionary method" dab shit. There're many other book on perspective better than his shitty course (check out the artbook thread and download Dongho Kim's book for more comprehensible book on perspective)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6432069
You don't need to do bargue plates, the first lessons of the book was but simple shapes. You can practice more simple things if the plates are too hard to handle (for now) until you are more comfortable to start that book again (like pic rel). The point of this is you get to know how to build your own visual library which you will need to do a lot later whenever you learn something new related to drawing. Accuracy practice is the first step everyone should do. After that you'll actually know what to do without anyone telling you.

Fineliners have a few advantages over using a gel pen or ballpoint, them being that it's almost impossible for them to bleed through paper and that the pigment will basically never wear out. posts.com:
Same, anon.
I'm trying to figure out how exactly tiktok works and it's actually worse than I expected.
Tiktok takes your location through IP address and recommends your content to people that have in common both the hashtag you put and your location. Meaning, if you're drawing for a very niche fandom or OC you can't get that far unless you spam videos like the plague to augment your chances of it spreading outside of your country, because literally everyone who likes/sees your video is from your country. Not to mention there's no sort by new search.
This is worse than twitter or Instagram because it inherently blocks distribution of content from smaller, non-corporate accounts. While on twitter and insta you can get 1k immediately with 1-2 posts if your art is good enough, tiktok just sends your video into a sample size of users from your country, which sucks ass if you're not american or Japanese/Chinese/Korean.

>>6427259
>>6428967
Tried out SG Pen and the Ink Brush, wasn't close to it. So I made this custom brush from a hodge podge of a bunch of brush materials I cannibalized.

I'm not particularly skilled at art, and especially at anime so sorry for the bad drawing. This was to see if I could get close to the original. It was drawn in 1600x2000 then cropped down mainly with the brush size between 12, 16, 20, 24, and 32 depending on what the line thickness is. It's not a good brush for a single line drawing. Instead, you'll have to draw over your lines multiple times to get it to be thick. Keep it light and fast for the "skippy" thin lines. I highly suggest holding your pen either the way Nagabe holds his pen for solid lines and a looser grip for the skippy ones.

https://files.catbox.moe/1ndnwq.sut

>>6428620
>img2img might help
>I am yet to see it do so with dragons

How It Works

2.1. Removing Noise
In a normal text-to-image run of Stable Diffusion, we feed the model some random noise. The model assumes, though, that this input is actually a piece of artwork that just had a bunch of noise added.

So, using the text prompt as a source of “hints” for what the (supposed) original looked like, it does its best to recover an image from the static. It does this over a bunch of steps (e.g., 50), gradually removing a little more noise each time.

With img2img, we do actually bury a real image (the one you provide) under a bunch of noise. And this causes Stable Diffusion to “recover” something that looks much closer to the one you supplied.

2.2. The Image/Noise Strength Parameter
There is a parameter which allows you to control how much the output resembles the input.

I'm not sure if img2img would be useful.
